overview.short: Frankia species are Gram-positive, aerobic, filamentous actinobacteria that form nitrogen-fixing symbioses with actinorhizal plants.
overview.clinical_context: Primarily environmental and plant-associated; human infection is extremely rare and usually represents contamination rather than true pathogenicity.

field_notes.Shape: Although filamentous in structure, Frankia is normalised to 'Rods' to remain compatible with the system shape schema.
field_notes.Spore Formation: Some species form specialised vesicles or spores related to nitrogen fixation.
field_notes.Growth: Frankia species are slow-growing and require specialised media; routine clinical media may show little or no growth.

key_differentiators.notes: Symbiotic nitrogen fixation with actinorhizal plants is unique to Frankia.
Non-fermentative metabolism supports exclusion of common Gram-positive cocci.
Aerobic growth helps separate Frankia from anaerobic or microaerophilic actinomycetes.

common_confusions.reason: Shared filamentous morphology and environmental origin.
Overlapping actinomycete features without acid-fast staining.

when_to_question_identification: Recovery from routine clinical specimens without environmental context.
Rapid growth on standard laboratory media.
Evidence of acid-fastness suggests alternative actinomycetes.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Frankia requires low-nutrient or specialised conditions for isolation.
Definitive identification due to limited biochemical differentiation.
Association with actinorhizal plants strongly supports Frankia.
